arbi-q.description: Adult Repetitive Behaviors and Interests Questionnaire

items.prompt: I have a strong desire to keep the same schedule or routine every day.
I have memorized a lot of facts about very specific or obscure topics.
While I focus on other things, I tend to fidget repetitively with nearby objects (e.g., rolling them between my fingers, bending/folding them, or tearing them apart).
Once I start doing something a certain way, I feel like it has to be done that way every time.
I like to repeat certain activities over and over again until they feel “just right.”
I often move my hands or fingers in ways that other people find unusual (e.g., flapping, flicking/twisting, tensing in certain positions).
I get so caught up in my interests that I skip meals or other important activities.
Unexpected changes of plans can cause me to break down emotionally.
I frequently pick at my skin, bite my nails, and/or tug at my hair.
I become upset when objects in my house are not “in their place.”
I like to repeatedly say certain words or phrases I've heard before (e.g., lines from movies or things someone else said).
I am much more bothered than other people by small changes in my daily routine.
I often look at objects in ways that most other people don't (e.g., out of the corner of my eye, at a very close distance).
When I am interested in a topic, I try to learn as much as I possibly can about it.
I have a hard time when I can't do something the way I am used to doing it.
I like to explore objects by running my hands across them.
Once I get started talking about my interests, I have a hard time changing the subject or letting others talk.
When I am thinking, I like to pace back and forth or walk in a specific pattern.
I become very upset when other people bend or break established rules.
I often feel the need to do or say specific things a certain number of times (e.g., locking the door exactly three times).
When I am stressed or overstimulated, I like to calm myself down by making repetitive movements (e.g., spinning around, rocking back and forth).
Other people get frustrated by how “stuck in my ways” (inflexible) I am.
I spend as much of my free time as possible engaging in a few specific activities.
I become fixated on certain thoughts or ideas and can't get my mind off them.
